title: (x) Glen Street Theatre - custom font {Paul Ross (self)}
content:
Hello folks,   
I've looked through the archives and no-one seems to have asked this question yet. I am trying to identify the typeface used by the Glen Street Theatre company here in Sydney, Australia. It is used throughout their website here...   
   
 [http://www.glenstreet.com.au/gst2/index.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103183005/http:/www.glenstreet.com.au/gst2/index.htm)   
   
Thanks & regards   
PAUL   
Some samples as well...   
 ![GST1](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103183005im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/26159.gif)   
 ![GST2](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103183005im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/26160.gif)   
 ![GST3](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103183005im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/26161.gif)

 [‹ BCBG Maxazria logo](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103183005/http:/www.typophile.com/node/3067 "Go to previous forum topic") [Bodoni Be Regular ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103183005/http:/www.typophile.com/node/3062 "Go to next forum topic")
author: skyrocket

comments.content: Looks like this could be found on [T-26](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103183005/http:/www.t26font.com/) ...

I looked at T-26 under techno, but no luck. Also tried dafont and larabie. But look again, sometimes I'm blind.   
   
Strange thing is, I could've sworn that we've had this ID before. Been looking the better part of this afternoon.
It's very similar (but not a match) for FF Trademarker Light

Karen/Yves/Sean,   
Thank you for looking. I too have spent a long time looking for this one. I now have a feeling it is a specially commissioned job. I am contacting the thatre directly to ask them as well and will post up their reply. It has quite an interesting/unusual look though doesn't it?

OK - I've done it again. This is a specially commissioned typeface and not one that is commercially available. I have just had an email from the designer and it was done especially for the Glen Street Theatre re-branding campaign a couple of years ago. The designer is Mark Gowing [http://www.markgowing.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20071103183005/http:/www.markgowing.com/) Sorry for putting anyone to any trouble. The typeface has no name and may become commercially available in a couple of years.

No need to apologize for posting this beauty. It works   
incredibly well in combination with their logo and its   
deconstructed elements. Very clever.   
_Mes compliments au chef._
